thread.title: Connally falls to Waco High in District 17-5A matchup
thread.title_full: Connally falls to Waco High in District 17-5A matchup | www.statesman.com

author: Sean Shapiro
title: Connally falls to Waco High in District 17-5A matchup
text:
Long passing plays doomed Connally to a 21-14 loss to Waco High on Thursday night in an oddity-filled football game at Cougar Stadium.
Waco (3-3, 1-1 in District 17-5A) completed only six passes in 18 attempts, but three of the completions went for touchdowns of 41 yards or longer.
“Three long plays, that was it,” Connally coach Jason Cecil said. “I thought the kids played well. It was just those long completions that really hurt us.”
Jamie Harms Connally quarterback Robert Patterson, looking to pass against Hutto last week in a District 17-5A matchup, threw and ran for a touchdown against Waco High on Thursday night, but the Cougars lost 21-14. (Jamie Harms/For American-Statesman) Originally scheduled to start at 7 p.m., the game was delayed 38 minutes after the officiating crew was caught in standstill traffic, the result of an overturned 18-wheeler on southbound Interstate 35 near Temple.
It was the first of two delays in a bizarre game that featured 202 penalty yards, including the ejection of LaCurtis Jones — a former Waco High and Baylor football player who was standing on the sidelines.
Early in the third quarter, Waco punter Alexis Arranaga was injured on a helmet-to-helmet play after a low snap. Arranaga was taken off the field on a stretcher, and the injury resulted in a 25-minute delay.
After the game, Waco coach Matt Herbst said Arranaga was moving his fingers and toes and was responsive to those caring for him at a nearby hospital.
Once the officials arrived at the field, Waco took control of the game on the opening drive. On the Lions’ third offensive play, Jalen Harris connected with Donnelle Swinnie for a 62-yard touchdown.
Connally (2-4, 0-2) punted on the ensuing series, and Harris capitalized with a 41-yard touchdown strike to LoDamien Calhoun down the left sideline.
Trailing 14-0, Connally blocked a punt before scoring on an 11-yard touchdown run by Robert Patterson.
Waco answered on its ensuing drive, as Harris connected with Swinnie on a 71-yard touchdown pass with 7 minutes, 6 seconds to go before halftime.
Connally scored the only touchdown of the second half two plays after the injury to Arranaga, when Patterson threw a 20-yard scoring pass to Mitchell Moorman.
St. Andrew’s 55, San Antonio Hawkins 12: Cole Baker rushed for two touchdowns and Evan Marshman threw for three scores and ran for a fourth as St. Andrew’s rolled to a road win in San Antonio.
The Crusaders (5-1) led 48-0 at halftime, as Blais Herman caught touchdown passes of 10 and 14 yards from Marshman and Baker scored on carries of 7 and 19 yards. Marshman also tossed a 26-yard TD pass to Alex Briggs, and the quarterback scored on a 4-yard run.
